choices.A: The policy configuration has never been imported after a device was registered on FortiManager.
choices.D: The policy package reports inconsistencies and conflicts during a Policy Consistency Check.
choices.C: The policy package configuration has been changed on both FortiManager and the managed device independently.
choices.B: The policy package does not have FortiGate as the installation target.

questions.question_text: What does a policy package status of Conflict indicate?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Correct. When changes are made to a policy package on FortiManager and the managed device independently of each other, this can lead to conflicts. The system recognizes discrepancies between the configurations stored on FortiManager and those active on the device, marking the status as Conflict because it cannot reconcile these differences without manual intervention.

Selected Answer: C
C manual page 222
Conflict: If you make policy configuration changes locally on FortiGate and don’t import the changes into
the policy package, and you also made the changes on FortiManager, the status enters conflict state.
Depending on the configuration changes, you can either import a policy package or install the changes from FortiManager.

Selected Answer: C
A policy package status of "Conflict" indicates that:

C. The policy package configuration has been changed on both FortiManager and the managed device independently.

This status arises when there are discrepancies between the policy configurations on FortiManager and the FortiGate device, due to changes being made locally on the FortiGate and also on the FortiManager, without synchronizing these changes. As a result, FortiManager cannot reconcile the differences automatically, leading to a conflict status. This requires manual intervention to resolve the differences and ensure the policy configurations are consistent across both platforms.

Selected Answer: C
correct

Selected Answer: D
Correct Answer is D.
I just tested it and when i created the new polciy package the global header&footer policies were added automatically.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct. Put that in a lab

Selected Answer: D
D. It automatically assigns the global policies.

When a new policy package is created in a custom ADOM (Administrative Domain) that already has a global policy package assigned to it, FortiManager automatically applies the global policies to the newly created policy package. This means that the global header and footer policies, which are part of the global policy package assigned to the ADOM, will be automatically included in the new policy package. This helps ensure consistency in policy enforcement across all policy packages within the ADOM and simplifies the management of common policies across different devices or sites managed within the same ADOM.

Selected Answer: D
D, tested in a LAB

How can customer or service provider administrators remove both global header and footer policies from the policy package named Shared_Package?

discussion.content: Actually none of the answers are correct, the correct answer would be "The service provider can exclude the Shared_Package policy package from the global package"

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.

//IMG//


An administrator wants to create a policy on the Staging ADOM in backup mode, and install it on the FortiGate device in the same ADOM.

How can the administrator perform this task?

choices.D: It allows FortiManager to act as a collector and FortiAnalyzer device.
choices.C: It allows FortiManager to store all managed FortiGate device logs.
choices.A: It allows FortiManager to manage all FortiGate devices.
choices.B: It allows FortiManager to run reports based on FortiAnalyzer.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Correct. When FortiManager is used to manage FortiAnalyzer, it can utilize the analytical and reporting capabilities of FortiAnalyzer directly. This means that administrators can run and access reports generated by FortiAnalyzer through the FortiManager interface, streamlining the process of monitoring and analyzing security data.

Selected Answer: B
B. It allows FortiManager to run reports based on FortiAnalyzer.

Integrating FortiManager with FortiAnalyzer provides several benefits, including the ability to run reports based on the log data collected and analyzed by FortiAnalyzer. FortiManager can leverage FortiAnalyzer's log management and analysis capabilities to generate comprehensive reports about network security threats, events, and system activities across all managed FortiGate devices. This integration simplifies the management and reporting processes, making it easier for administrators to obtain insights and make informed decisions regarding their network security posture.

Answer B, Page 14 Study Guide
FortiManager gives visibility into the logs on FortiAnalyzer, providing a single pane of glass on FortiManager.
When FortiManager manages a FortiAnalyzer device, all configuration and data is kept on FortiAnalyzer to support the following FortiAnalyzer features:
• FortiView
• Log View
• Incidents & Events
• Reports

questions.question_text: What is the advantage of using FortiManager to manage FortiAnalyzer?
